abstracts.cdata!:
Overall this report rates the
            project's outcome as unsatisfactory. Related to the
            long term goal of the project, i.e. modernization of the
            Ministry and establishment of conditions that would ensure
            sustainability of road rehabilitation and maintenance over
            time (creation of a road fund, increased utilization of the
            private sector, devolution of responsibilities for road
            maintenance at the municipal level, a reformed Ministry for
            Public Works), the outcome of the project remains uncertain.
            Sustainability of the project as a whole is uncertain,
            though sustainability of the various physical components is
            clearly likely. The Bank's performance is overall rated
            unsatisfactory, although marginally. The project preparation
            was thorough. The Bank closely supervised the implementation
            of the physical components and of the action plans, despite
            the persisting security problems in the country and
            dwindling commitment from the MIRP to the reform objective.
            However, the Bank was in a way unable to provide the needed
            guidance to the GoA to implement the project in the early
            years of project implementation. Bank's supervision
            also focused on delivery of components and failed to
            sufficiently analyze how this would influence the outcome of
            the project and hence the attainment of the project
            objectives. Borrower's performance is rated
            unsatisfactory. Performance was satisfactory during project
            preparation and in the last years of implementation, but
            unsatisfactory during the first half of project's
            implementation. the Borrower failed to pursue the
            project's goals and to implement many of the reform
            actions, which it insisted be included during project
            preparation. Lessons learned pertained 1) to the complexity
            of project design in an uncertain county environment with
            weak institutions existing, the need for a condition of
            effectiveness to test client commitment; 2) inadequate
            coordination among agencies and ministries and the need of
            the Bank to set in place mechanisms to facilitate
            implementation; 3) the absence of an adequate financial
            system, which made it difficult to have reliable information
            on project disbursements and funds; 4) the too cursory
            analysis of risks during appraisal; 5) the need of
            supervision missions to focus on long-term goals in addition
            to short term issues and delivery of outputs; and 6) the
            lack of counterpart funds, which created major delays and
            tensions, along with the need to closely coordinate between
            the sectoral and the finance ministries during supervision.

18225082.majtheme: Rural development,Financial and private sector development,Public sector governance

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Sixth Highway
            Project is to enhance the capabilities of Algeria to manage
            its road sector by: 1) reducing the backlog of roads and
            bridges in need of rehabilitation and maintenance; 2)
            strengthening the agency responsible for the management and
            maintenance of roads; 3) providing sustainable solutions to
            finance road rehabilitation and maintenance works; and 4)
            creating an environment conducive to the efficient
            utilization of human and financial resources in the road
            sector, in particular through increased competition,
            participation of the private sector and implementation of a
            quality improvement strategy. The project will finance road
            rehabilitation works by strengthening high-traffic basic
            economic network pavements; rehabilitating medium-traffic
            national roads with appropriate low-cost technologies;
            rehabilitating priority bridges; and related design and
            supervision. The project will also finance road maintenance
            through periodic maintenance by contract for national roads;
            purchasing of equipment for current and emergency
            maintenance of Saharan tracks and for traffic counting;
            providing technical assistance for and executing a pilot
            program for maintenance of municipal roads; and related
            supervision, general studies and training.
